Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2018 06:29AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Leee, your post touched me. I know how scary this is. There are good treatments, and more are on the way. I was first diagnosed with liver and bone mets in 2012. It's not been easy, but it has been do-able, and life for me has been good these past 77 months--much longer than I thought I'd have. I don't have advice, because our circumstances and our bodies are all different, but I offer my support and prayers. I do find that living in each day as it comes (trite, I know, but true) has been my constant challenge and strength, and I am amazed at how those individual days become weeks, months, and years. (My oncologist told me yesterday I was in much better shape now than I was in July, 2012, which made me recall his comment to me when he told me of liver mets: "We can make it better." I do so hope the same for you. Peace and blessings.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 09:12PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Oh, I so agree with you, Bouncing Betties!  Thank you for writing this.  I hate to hear, "She has such a good attitude."  or "If anybody can beat this, you can."  I had a really long remission or NED or whatever with Stage III recurrence (over 22 1/2 years).  Now that the cancer's back, people say "You beat it before.  You'll beat it again, and get another 23 years."  GRRRRR!  Not the same--it's liver and bones now.  But I just smile, although sometimes I say it's different this time.  And sometimes I say that, no, I didn't always have a good attitude.  Sometimes I was sad, sometimes I was mad.  And I even made tentative funeral plans.  How was that for a good attitude??!! Oh, I hate hearing about good attitude, as if that will be our cure.  I believe most of us have the best attitude we can, but we should not feel guilty or that we have jeopardized our well-being because we have moments of fear or sadness or anger.  That would be unrealistic for any person.  I do think that many of us try to spare others, and for their sakes we muster up a "good attitude"  even when we don't truly feel it. About the only things that rile me as much are these: 1.  PINK, in all its merchandised glory 2.  So and so died after a "courageous battle with cancer" I have turned into a curmudgeon tonight.  Whatever has happened to my attitude?
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 07:32PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Glenna, I was so interested to read your post.  I also was first diagnosed in 1987.  2 years at stage 1, 22 1/2 at stage 3, and since last summer at stage 4.  My family and close friends also think that since I had such a long (unexpected at the time) remission, that surely that will happen again.  "You had 23 years since the other recurrence, and you'll get another 23 years.  You're a fighter, and the medicines are better, etc., etc."  Sometimes I just get tired of hearing it, even though they mean well.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 09:02AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Chickadee, I love your comment about pink warriors dancing in the streets.  I cringe when I see things like "race for the cure" or "run so that others may live."  Maybe the original intent was good, but the grouchy person in me sees that as a pink insurance policy.  I hate the October stuff--the beautification of breast cancer.  The ads look like the old commercials for feminine hygiene products.  And I am not a warrior.  I am a nice, little older woman who is doing her best to live each day.  I used to be a nice, little younger woman who did her best to live each day--nothing more, nothing less.  I don't feel any heroics, and I don't want qualities attributed to me that I don't have.  Probably I'm just pissy today (too old to be PMS-y).  It's good to be able to voice these thoughts with people who understand, and some who even feel the same, because I won't/can't utter them otherwise--people would counter with positive platitudes.  Thanks!!
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 11:07PM SchnauzerMom wrote: I agree with all of you who have said how unrealistic it is to be up all the time.  That is artificial for most people, regardless of circumstances.  When you add just the fatigue and uncertainty of this disease, that makes perpetual positivity even less likely.  Then when we consider loss that has already occurred, or worse, contemplate future losses, what sort of emotional artifice would make a person positive all the time?  I try very consistently to keep my down time as brief and as private as I can (don't know if that's good or not, really), but there are moments when I think, what a relief it would be not to dread--just die and get it over with.  Thank goodness those times are brief, but they do exist.  And the moment that thought is formed, I think, "no, not yet--didn't really mean it".  But the thought does flicker.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 04:17PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Hello All.  I just discovered this thread, and I am moved by your stories.  There are so many of us--all so different and yet so much in common.  I've been lurking for a while, and only recently have posted.  Probably time to introduce myself, since I've already barged in. I am Judy.  First diagnosed in 1987 with a 4mm. tumor (lumpectomy, radiation).  The thing came back in 1989 (termed regional metastasis, stage III--cytoxan, 5-fu, methotrexate).  Had bone marrow harvest in 1990, strongly recommended by oncologist.  Paid out-of- pocket--ouch!!  I asked the doctor directing the program at med center how long the harvest would keep.  His answered, "Definitely at least five years, but don't worry, you'll need it before then."  I think that stuff is still probably in a freezer somewhere, since bone marrow transplants aren't done for breast cancer these days.  Took Tamoxifen for 11 years. In July, 2012 I had a routine physical.  (At husband's urging/nagging--just had been going downhill in energy)  Turned out I had anemia.  Further investigation, turned out I had bone and liver mets.  Yowza!!! Did not see that coming, but do any of us, really?  Started Femara, Xgeva, Faslodex the day of diagnosis.  PET scan in January showed bone regression, but liver progression, so have added Taxol and Avastin. I am 66--one of the elders.  I was 41 with a kindergartener when first diagnosed.  My heart breaks for the young women--if I could take your disease, truly I would.  I have had so much time that I never expected to have, and for which I am most grateful.  I would love more time, but I have been gifted beyond measure with life to raise my children and even to have grandchildren.   I have been married to a wonderful man for 45 years.  We have four children:  three of them are 38-years-old (they were quadruplets, but we lost a little boy at 8 days), and a 29-year-old (it took nine years to get up the courage to try that again)!  We have seven grandchildren, and another to come in May. I was a high school special education teacher (now retired), and LOVED it!!!!!  My husband is a retired professor who plays lots of golf.  His passion for golf is matched by mine for sewing.  I love to sew, and have made my own clothes since high school.  (Love dressmaking and tailoring.  A somewhat serious concern is what will eventually become of my enormous stash of fabrics.) We have the most affectionate schnauzer there could be.  His name is Arnie, and he loves without measure. I love to read, and my favorites are all of C.S. Lewis and very glad to have found Lady Julian of Norwich. So glad to meet you all.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 12:37PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Hello.  So glad to see your post--it encouraged me to stop lurking, too.  I also have (had, as most of it has now fallen out) red hair.  I, too, have stage iv with liver, rib, skull, pelvic mets as of July 31. 2012.  First diagnosed with a 4mm. lobular carcinoma November 11, 1987 (treated with lumpectomy and 6-weeks radiation), then diagnosed December 11, 1989 with stage iii regional metasasis (5-Fu, cytoxan, methotrexate for 6 months and Tamoxifen for 11 years.  NED until last year!!!  Nearly 23 years!  I think nobody wants to think this disease can return after that long, and I feel like the embodiment of all that pre-stage iv diagnosees fear about breast cancer--I strike terror into women's hearts, and I feel crummy about that. I have been on Femara, Faslodex, and X-geva since July 31st last year.  Recent scan, January 15th,  showed growth in liver lesions, so have had added Taxol and Avastin.  Hoping for some shrinkage!! Glad to meet you all!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2017 05:02AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Laurie, I am so sorry that you have liver metastasis. Me, too, for nearly five years now. I thought time was far more limited when I first got the diagnosis, but here I am, and with a pretty good quality of life. I've had many lines of treatment, some worked, and more did not. It was always discouraging when a treatment was ineffective, and like all of us, I dread waiting for scan results and tumor markers. The tumors have never gone away, but blood work is always reasonably normal. Currently I'm on Halaven (past 6 months). My longest stretch of good response was with Doxil (20 months). I know we're all different in our responses to treatments--some promising ones didn't work for me, but others did. There is hope for more time. Wishing you well!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2015 02:22AM SchnauzerMom wrote: I agree so much with what you've said about feeling so bad for the younger women living with this disease. I had a recurrence (stage 3) in 1989, and feared so much that I would leave my children (youngest was in kindergarten) without a mother. Could I have known then that I would have until 2012 before the disease roared back, I would have so gratefully said yes--I'll so gladly take those terms!! I feel like I was given all those years, for whatever reason, and it's almost as if my "note came due". I'm really not mad about it--would rather it hadn't progressed to stage 4, but so glad it was later rather than sooner. But . . . Still . . . we do have concerns, uncertainties, losses, and bodies that hurt. This is not an enviable situation even as an older woman. Are there worse situations? Oh, yes. But, here we are in our present situations, trying to live our lives, often trying to make the best of it for other people, and trying to deal with declining hardiness. I am glad for a place we can speak freely with people who understand!!

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2015 07:21PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Crone and Tina2, I agree with you about reading "Being Mortal." I just finished it this morning. A short passage in the epilogue has so much wise guidance. "Whenever serious sickness or injury strikes and your body or mind breaks down, the vital questions are the same. What is your understanding of the situation and its potential outcomes? what are your fears and what are your hopes? What are the trade-offs you are willing to make and not wiling to make? And what is the course of action that best serves this understanding?" I have not yet done any medical directives, but I am going to start now! Also, I have thought that I should write down some reminiscences and stories to pass down to my grandchildren, but I haven't started that either. It's probably time. I have reservations, though, that the recollections will be only as accurate as my perspective and memory allow. I guess, though, that's how any of our own stories must be. I have three teenaged grandchildren, and I have told them about my diagnosis (and they certainly can google and have googled, so they know). I plan to tell my 12 and 8 year old grandsons fairly soon. The little ones, who are 3 and under, I won't tell. Maybe???? Up to their parents. They know that medicine has made my hair fall out. When I don't wear my wig at home, one of the little girls says, "Grandma, put on your 'lots of hair'." Such delightful honesty! and what a good name for my wig! What hair that has come back looks like my schnauzer's fur--not pretty on a human who still has a bit of vanity left. (Not much, but some.)

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 09:44PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Nanaphyl, I'm so sorry you are dealing with cancer again.  (I recurred with liver and bone mets last summer after 22.5 years--never saw it coming after that much time.)  The day of diagnosis I started with Femara, Xgeva, and Faslodex, and have been on them since.  Side effects with those drugs have been quite tolerable for me.  PET scan in January showed grest improvement with bones, but progression in liver.  Since then I've also been on Taxol and Avastin.  (3 weeks on, 1 off for Taxol and every other week for Avastin.)  I have a lot of fatigue with the chemo (or maybe it is the combination), and I have lost my hair, and have some neuropathy to hands and feet.  After this cycle is over, it will be scan time again.  If liver is better, my oncologist is thinking about stopping the Taxol and Avastin.    (I had my first recurrence in 1989, and had CMF and took Tamoxifen for 11 years.  After first having bc in 1987, I had  "segmental mastectomy--big lumpectomy, I think, and radiation, but no other meds.) Hope you and your doctor find a treament regimen that kicks that cancer's butt.  You will probably be hearing from many of us about a variety of treaments and medications.  It is so good that there are options. This is a rough path to travel some days, but you will have support and understanding from wonderful people on this forum.  I have been very grateful to have found this site, and I'm glad you have found your way here, too.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 09:57AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Renae, I wish so much that this were not so hard.  My heart goes out to you, truly.  Not that my story will give you ease, but there might be something, and it is in that hope that I offer it. I had regional mets in 1989, and at that time my previous oncologist (and doctors who did bone marrow harvest) were not optimistic.  I pressed for a time frame, and was told three years if I was lucky, although he'd known of someone who'd had five. I know that all of that seems archaic now, and regional metasases are not what we are dealing with now.  Yet, I did feel that my future was very foreshortened and that I wouldn't be with my husband and childrern.  My youngest daughter was in kindergarten, and the recurrence came at the time of her school Christmas program (parochial school).  I went out and bought her Christmas dresses for  the next three years, labelled the years, and hung  them in her closet.  Small preparations, like that. After a few months, I got more levelled and decided I could not live in the future, only right now.  Each morning I thanked God for this day, and asked myself, "Are you going to die today?"  I'd think, "NO, not today."  Then, somehow, I'd be happy  for that day.  Sometimes the dread would overwhelm me, and I suspected each ache and pain, but the good days grew in number.   After 22 years and 7 months I was taken by utter surprise with liver and bone mets.  (Clean mammograms--all three times, though!!????)  Most days I marvel at the enormous gift of time and life I had, and just think that my note finally  had come due. (Some days, though, it pisses me off!)   At any rate, what seems to help me was/is living in the day, not looking too far ahead.    Sending you good wishes and a heartfelt prayer.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 11:41AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Naniem, your preferences and mine are very much the same.  I would greatly prefer hospice (in a hospice facility).  Although many people receive hospice services in their homes, that is not my choice.  I think I'd feel more certain of pain control in a facility, and I truly do not want my husband or daughters to become responsible for round-the-clock care.  My mother died of skin cancer (mets to lung and brain), and my father who was 77 at the time did his utmost to care for her, but he was exhausted and injured from lifting, even with hospice service (minimal) in the home. In retrospect, I don't think my mother would have wanted that, and I don't want that for my family.  I know they will visit me, but they will have a place to sleep without being constantly on alert.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2018 03:39PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Shetland Pony, I see that we do have some strong similarities in our diagnoses. I will try to answer your questions about my treatments in the hope that the information could be useful to you. (First, a disclaimer: I have had trouble entering/updating treatment info, so there are missing dates and a missing chemo on the list as it appears, so I will correct those below. I guess I'll list meds and the strategy (as I perceive it) chronologically. Here goes: 11/21/1987: 1st diagnosis ILC, 4mm. lumpectomy, radiation 12/11/1989: recurrence, regional involvement, CMF (cytoxan, methotrexate, 5-FU) Tamoxifen from 1990 - 2001 7/31/2012: 1st PET scan: metasasis to liver and bones , Faslodex, Xgeva, Femara [Oncologist thought that hormonals would be a good start] 1/2013: 2nd PET scan: progression in liver, added Taxol and Avastin and continued the Faslodex, Xgeva, Femara. Oncologist still held some hope for the hormonal, but wanted to zap the liver mets with chemo. 6/2013: 3rd PET scan: liver and bones showed regression, but blood developed a form of myelodysplastic syndrome, so stopped Taxol and Avastin, but continued Faslodex, Xgeva, Femara. 11/2013: 4th PET scan: progression to liver and bones. started Abraxane, stopped Faslodex and Femara. 4/2014: 5th PET scan: progression to liver and bones, started Navelbine 7/2014: 6th PET scan: progression to liver and bones, started Aromasin and Afinitor 11/2014: 7th PET scan: progression to liver and bones (not looking too promising) , started Doxil 5/2015: 8th PET scan: regression in bones and liver, continued Doxil, had EKG, Echo, MUGA to assess heart--okay 8/9/2015-8/16/2015: hospitalized with Ludwig's angina (jaw infection), osteonecrosis of jaw 6/2016: 9th PET scan: progression to bones (a great 19 month run on Doxil!!!!), stopped Doxil, started Xeloda 12/2016: 10th PET scan: progression to liver and bones, stopped Xeloda, started Halaven 6/2017: 11th PET scan: progression to liver and bones, oncologist thought it would be worth trying Tamoxifen again since I'd had a long disease-free period on it years ago, even though none of the newer hormonals had worked for me since metastasis. We all thought, "What can it hurt?" So I started Tamoxifen! 2/2018: 12th PET scan: regression in liver and bones--tumors smaller--best PET scan I've had, continued with Tamoxifen. (I told my oncologist he's a genius,and he grinned and said "I know." He is great!) 7/2018: 13th PET scan: progression in liver and bones. Started Verzenio.  If you have read this entire post, you must be exhausted. I will think about your other question about what might have helped me, and I'll collect my thoughts and post again (be forewarned!!!)

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2019 01:28PM SchnauzerMom wrote: JFL, I see that we have taken many of the same meds. You are heavily pretreated, too! Which have been most successful for you? For me, it was Doxil--almost 20 months. I'd taken Tamoxifen for nearly11 years after my first recurrence in 1989. (I know that was longer than typical for the time, but there really were not alternatives, and I was staying healthy.) After progression on Halaven in 2017, my oncologist (whom I truly respect) said he thought it would be worth trying Tamoxifen again (it had been about 17 years since I'd had it). I was running out of options. There was Gemzar yet to be tried, and Verzenio had not yet been approved. Well, It worked very well for a little more for more than a year and I felt great!! If you do decide on Tamoxifen, I wish you good results, too. For me, it was a wonderful revisit! (And now on to Verzenio, which is rougher but I'm hopeful.)

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2015 08:36PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Allyme, so wonderful to hear your good results!! Yes, I so agree with you about staying with medicine. Could your parents accept that faith and medicine are not mutually exclusive, but together can sustain and sometimes heal? The mother of my daughter's best friend was diagnosed with stage III breast cancer two weeks after I was diagnosed with Stage IV. She wanted to rely on prayer and a strict diet. She did well for a few months, but sadly died 14 months after her diagnosis--on her daughter's birthday. She was a well-intentioned, devout woman, who felt that she would not be wholly reliant on God if she chose to combine her options with medicine. My heart broke for her daughter. Please, please do not feel that you are disappointing your parents. Perhaps they can pray with in concert with the medicines--pray for the specific medicines (by name, even) to work within your body. Use all the graces available to you, and the medicines and medical practitioners are major graces! Many good wishes and blessings to you.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 11:49PM SchnauzerMom wrote: When my oncologist recommended a port, I thought ,"Whoa, this is serious!"  Duh!  As if I didn't already know that.  I'd had chemo at stage III 23 years ago, and didn't have a port.  My forearm vein became a very visible brown--seemed like a chemo label at the time.  I assumed procedure still would be the same again.  The needles have never bothered me, but the vein tattoos did. I 'm glad to have gone with the port--it's easy and discreet.  I know it's personal preference, but I am glad to avoid the staining (which I assumed implied some sort of injury to the vein).  Whatever you choose, it's just good we have access to some powerful medicines.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2019 08:15PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Elderberry, This is a very hard time. Your feelings are so normal and so understandable. I see that you were diagnosed with liver mets. Me, too, almost seven years ago. The liver mets scared me, and I thought my prognosis was short because of them. I've had a lot of different treatments, and several failed, but some have worked well. And I'm still here with a reasonably good quality of life. There is hope!!! Herceptin is a good medicine And there are more, and more on the way. Congratulations on your long and happy marriage! There is an excellent chance you will have more good years together. We had just celebrated our 45th anniversary the month I was diagnosed. Didn't expect to be here for our 50th, but I was. 52 coming up soon! (And they've been good and happy years.) Do take care of yourself. You didn't cause this. It feels like life has exploded, but some normalcy will return. All good wishes!

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 05:57PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Chickadee, I so agree!  It is hard whenever , regardless.  I think of that line from Emily Dickinson:  "Parting is all we know of heaven, and all we need of hell."  It is the parting, and as long as there are people whom we love here, the parting is hard.  When I first recurred 23 years ago, my children were young, and I dreaded so to leave them (stage III, but onocologist then was very pessimistic).  By whatever grace, I have had all these years.  It is not as hard this time for me, but I still am sad, I still don't want to leave, and I still want to be with my husband, children and grandchildren (that I thought I would never see).  My heart breaks for the mothers of young children, but I feel sad for those of us who have had more time, too.   (And damn that stuff coming back after 23 years!!  Damn that cancer whenever if threatens us!  But if I could give the young mothers 23 years, oh, how I would!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2018 09:23AM SchnauzerMom wrote: Tina, I understand your concern. Does your mother have any swelling in the jaw or neck area? The fevers do suggest the possibility of infection. If there is any swelling, please get her to the doctor immediately. I have had ongoing problems with ONJ since 2015. Most of it was controlled by antibiotics. However, in August, 2015,while visiting my daughter in Seattle, I developed swelling, and just felt unwell with a low-grade fever. After hoping it would improve, we finally went to a walk-in clinic on a Sunday (duh!!!) After a 3-hour wait to be seen, I was sent to an emergency room, where I was immediately diagnosed with Ludwig's Angina (had never heard of it), then sent by ambulance to another hospital where I had surgery immediately, and remained in the hospital for 8 days. Recovered well, but it was frightening and painful. Not suggesting this is your mother's case, but do be aware of it, especially with the fevers. Private message me, if you'd like. Hoping for the best for you and your mother. Judy

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 03:22PM SchnauzerMom wrote: Mary-Lou, I was diagnosed with liver and bone mets two a little over two years ago.  At that time my liver functions were somewhat abnormal.  After diagnosis I was on only Faslodex and Femara for almost six months.  That combo helped the bones, but I had liver progression.  I had then had six months of Taxol and Avastin, which did reduce both liver and bone mets, but I developed  myelodysplastic syndrome, so had to quit Taxol and Avastin.  I was back to only Faslodex and Femara for almost six months, but had significant progression.  It was on to Abraxane for four months with more progression, then  Navelbine for over three months, again with progression.  During all these progressions, liver function has stayed normal!  ?????  I feel fairly well, and am reasonably active.  I tell myself that as long as my liver continues to function normally, I will be okay.  I'm on Afinitor and Aromasin now, and hoping for good results.  If not, there are still some chemos I've not yet had.  The time I've had since the liver mets diagnosis has been good, and I'm reasonably optimistic there could be more time.  Do hang in there.  Liver metastasis is scary, but it's not an imminent death sentence. I wish you well.
